title-group.article-title: Electrorheological properties of polyaniline/K-feldspar conducting composite

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Chemistry, Gazi University, 06500 Ankara, Turkey
2Department of Chemistry, Ankara University, 06100 Ankara, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: H. Ibrahim Unal, Department of Chemistry, Gazi University, 06500 Ankara, Turkey Email: hiunal@gazi.edu.tr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this study, synthesis of conducting polyaniline (PAn)/potassium-feldspar (K-feldspar) composites, having various amounts of PAn, was carried out using (NH4)2S2O8 as oxidizing agent. The conducting composites were characterized by a series of techniques namely: Fourier transform–infrared, X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, thermogravimetry analysis, two-probe conductivity, magnetic susceptibility, and particle size measurements. For electrorheological (ER) measurements, the conductivities of the composites were reduced by a dedoping process. A series of suspensions were prepared in silicone oil, having various volume fractions, and then subjected to colloidal stability, flow rate, ER and creep-recovery tests. Enhancement in the electric field-induced viscosities and shear thinning non-Newtonian viscoelastic behavior was observed for all the composite materials studied. Recoverable viscoelastic deformations were detected from the creep and creep-recovery tests under externally applied electric field thus; they were classified as smart materials.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Because of their physical and chemical properties, conducting polymers have attracted both scientists and the industrial applicants. Within these, polyaniline (PAn) is the most frequently used conducting polymer because of its excellent conductivity, environmental stability, and superior redox properties. Since, conducting polymers of aniline show inefficiencies during their processing operations such as melting, solubility, and mechanical properties; their composites are prepared with various organic and/or inorganic mineral clays1–5 through micellar media,6 interfacial,7 or template-guided polymerization.8

Clay minerals are especially preferred materials for the preparation of conducting composites because of their wide surface areas and intercalation capabilities.9–11 Also, it is possible to prepare micro- and nano-structured PAn composites having high thermal stabilities, mechanical strengths, and desired electrical properties by controlling the bulk properties of PAn.

Recent studies are focused on the electrorheological (ER) properties of pure polymers,12,13 inorganic- or organic-based composites,14,15 semiconducting polymers,16–18 and their composites and/or nanocomposites.19–21 Good ER performances are reported for PAn and its derivatives,22–24 polypyrrole,25 and their copolymers.12,26

From the ER point of view, conductivity is one of the desired properties of PAn that must be controlled rather than trying to enhance when composites are formed. To obtain a high-yield stress for ER fluids, conductivity of the material must be within the limits of 1 × 10−5 > σ > 1 × 10−8 Sm−1. It is well known that electrical conductivity of a composite is generally dependent on the amount of PAn present. At low PAn loadings, conductivity of composites is reported to be very close to that of pure matrix material. At the critical loading, called percolation threshold, conductivity increases in the orders of several magnitudes with a very little increase in the PAn content. At percolation threshold, continuous conductive network through the composite begins to form. After this region of drastic enhancement, conductivity once again levels off and its value become closer to that of free PAn.27

In this study, PAn/K-feldspar composites were prepared having various amounts of PAn, suitable for ER study, by in situ oxidative polymerization using (NH4)2S2O8 as oxidizing agent. After their characterization by various techniques, antisedimentation stability, electrorheology, and creep and creep-recovery tests were conducted and the PAn/K-feldspar composite classified as a viscoelastic smart material and having vibration damping capability under externally applied electric field.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The chemical composition of K-feldspar, which is kindly provided by Eczacıbası ESAN Co., of Istanbul is as following: Al2O3: 17%; SiO2: 65%; K2O: 17%; Na2O: 1.1%; Fe2O3: 0.09%. Aniline (Aldrich) was used after vacuum distillation. Silicone oil (SO) was provided from Aldrich (ρ = 0.965 g cm−3, η = 200 mPa s, ε = 2.61 at 25°C). All the other chemicals were analytical grade Merck products and used as received.

sec.title: Preparation of PAn/K-feldspar composite
sec.p:
PAn/K-feldspar composites were synthesized by chemical oxidation method as described elsewhere,28 using (NH4)2S2O8 as an oxidizing agent. 0.1 M, 17 mL HCl(aq) was added into a polymerization vessel containing 2 g K-feldspar particles and kept stirring for 10 min. A desired amount of aniline monomer was added onto this solution with vigorous stirring. Then, 3 mL aliquot of 0.025 M (NH4)2S2O8 (dissolved 0.1 M HCl) were added dropwise into this mixture and the polymerization reaction was carried out for 2 h at 0°C. At the end of composite formation reaction, the crude product was recovered by centrifugation and washed with distilled water, methanol, and 1.0 M HCl (to redope the composite), respectively, to remove any residual oxidant, unreacted aniline, and oligomers present. Then, the composites were dried in a vacuum oven at 50°C for 24 h, weighed and the content of PAn was determined gravimetrically for each composition. The codings and compositions of PAn/K-feldspar composites are given in Table 1. Table 1.
Some physical properties and antisedimentation ratios of samples
Material codings and contents Aniline (mol L−1) σ × 102 (doped) (S cm−1) σ × 105 (partially undoped) (S cm−1) Average particle size (d0.5, µm) Density (g cm−3) Sedimentation ratioa (φ = 5%)
K-feldspar – – – 11 1.492 11
PAn (3.1%)/K-feldspar (96.9) (K4) 0.05 6.1 5.21 11 1.029 14
PAn (7.03%)/K-feldspar (92.97) (K3) 0.15 175 210 12 1.023 19
PAn (13.6%)/K-feldspar (86.4) (K2) 0.25 240 430 6 1.021 20
PAn (20.4%)/K-feldspar (79.6) (K1) 0.5 554 770 4.5 0.994 24
a
in SO, at the end of 20 days.

sec.title: Characterization techniques
sec.p: Fourier transform–infrared (FTIR) spectra of all the samples were recorded using a Mattson 1000 Model FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets at the spectral resolution of 16. Conductivities of the samples (1 × 13 mm2 pellets) were measured using a Keithley 6517 A electrometer by two probe technique. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out using a Sherwood Scientific model Gouy balance. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) diffractograms were obtained on a Rigaku Ultima-IV model X-ray diffractometer using Co-Kα radiation (2θ = 2–70°). Thermogravimetry analysis (TGA) were carried out by 10°C min−1 heating rate using a Shimadzu DTA-60 H, DSC-60 thermal analyzer under N2(g) atmosphere. The surface morphologies of the samples were examined by QUANTA 400 F model scanning electron microscopy (SEM).

The ground milled samples were subjected to particle size measurements using a Malvern Mastersizer E, version 1.2 b particle size analyzer. The data collected were evaluated according to the Fraunhofer diffraction theory by the Malvern software computer.29 The average particle sizes of the composites are given in Table 1.

sec.title: Preparation of suspensions
sec.p: PAn/K-feldspar composites and SO were vacuum dried in an oven for 24 h at 60°C and 110°C, respectively, to remove any moisture present. Then, suspensions of PAn/K-feldspar composites were prepared in SO at a series of volume fractions (φ = 5–25% V/V), by dispersing definite amount of dispersed phase in calculated amount of continuous phase (SO) according to the formula: (1)

sec.title: Antisedimentation stability measurements
sec.p: Antisedimentation stabilities of the suspensions were determined at T = 25 ± 0.1°C. Glass tubes containing the suspensions at φ = 5% were immersed into a constant temperature water bath and recorded the height of phase separation between the particle-rich phase and the relatively clear oil-rich phase as a function of time. The antisedimentation ratio was defined by the height percentage of the particle-rich phase relative to the total suspension height.

sec.title: Electrorheological measurements
sec.p: ER properties of the suspensions were determined with a Termo-Haake RS600 parallel plate torque electrorheometer. The gap between the parallel plates was 1.0 mm and the diameters of the upper and lower plates were 35 mm. The potential used in these experiments was also supplied by a 0–12.5 kV (with 0.5 kV increments) dc electric field generator (Fug Electronics, HCL 14, Germany), which enabled resistivity to be created during the experiments. All the ER measurements were carried out at constant temperature (T = 25°C), except the temperature sweep (T = 15–80°C), either at a controlled rate (CR) or controlled stress mode (CS).

sec.title: Creep-recovery measurements
sec.p: During the creep and creep-recovery experiment, a constant stress was applied instantaneously to K1/SO system at constant conditions (φ = 20%, T = 25°C, E = 0 kV mm−1, and E ≠ 0 kV mm−1) and change in strain (γ) was measured over a period of time. Then, the stress was set to zero and with this measurement, the recoverable elastic portion of the deformation was determined.

sec.title: Characterization studies
sec.p:
In this study, PAn/K-feldspar composites at various compositions were successfully prepared and the results obtained are discussed below. Expected distinctive absorptions are observed for the FTIR spectra of both K-feldspar and PAn.28 The wide band at 1000–1200 cm−1 was arising from the K-feldspar component (Figure 1(a)) of the composite, which is overlapped with the conductance band at 1140 cm−1 belonging to PAn. The bands at 1577 and 1481 cm−1 are arising from C = C stretching of quinoid and benzenoid rings (Figure 1(b)) in PAn. The band at 1302 cm−1 belongs to secondary C–N stretching in PAn chains. In the FTIR spectrum of PAn/K-feldspar composite (Figure 1(c)), the above-mentioned peaks, belonging to PAn and K-feldspar were also observed, proofing successful formation of the composite. Figure 1.
FTIR spectra of: (a) K-feldspar, (b) HCl-doped PAn, and (c) PAn (20.4%)/K-feldspar.

XRD patterns of K-feldspar, PAn, and PAn/K-feldspar composite samples are shown in Figure 2(a)–(c), respectively. Crystalline structure of the K-feldspar has not changed, but the peaks in 2θ = 20–35° were slightly widened, due to the predominantly amorphous PAn particles covered on to the surface of the crystalline-dominant (79.6%) K-feldspar particles. Figure 2.
XRD patterns: (a) K-feldspar, (b) HCl-doped PAn, and (c) PAn (20.4%)/K-feldspar.

SEM micrographs of K-feldspar and PAn/K-feldspar composite are given in Figure 3 (a) and (b). Big granular structure was observed for K-feldspar having smaller particles dispersed on the surfaces. SEM image of the composite revealed a sponge-like structure of PAn component covering the surface of the K-feldspar particles and indicating a composite structure formation.28 Figure 3.
SEM micrographs of: (a) K-feldspar and (b) PAn (20.4%)/K-feldspar.

The TGA thermograms of K-feldspar, PAn, and PAn/K-feldspar composite are given in Figure 4. K-feldspar was thermally the most stable and no weight loss was observed between 30°C and 900°C. PAn showed two step decomposition with a 51% weight loss at 230°C and 325°C. PAn/K-feldspar composite showed a 6.5% weight loss between the same temperature ranges, starting from 360°C, which indicates a higher thermal stability for the composite when compared to PAn.28 Figure 4.
TGA thermograms of: (a) K-feldspar, (b) HCl doped PAn, and (c) PAn (20.4%)/K-feldspar.

Table 1 shows the materials used, their codings, PAn content (%), average hydrodynamic particle size (d0.5), and conductivities (σ) of both doped and partially undoped PAn/K-feldspar composites. There are two main factors which affect the PAn content and σ of the composites. First, a gradual increase was observed for the σ and PAn content of doped composites resulting with σ = 554 × 10−2 S cm−1 conductivity and 20.4% PAn content at [Aniline] = 0.5 M and T = 0°C conditions. Since, the σ of the composites were relatively high for the ER studies, they were partially undoped by rinsing with pH = 9 NaOH(aq) solution for 1 h, to deprotonate PAn at the surface of PAn/K-feldspar composite (Table 1). After the undoping process, the σ of the composites were changed between 5.21 × 10−5 ≤ σ ≤ 7.7 × 10−3 S cm−1, which was suitable for ER measurements.30
As expected, average particle sizes and densities of the materials were slightly decreased with increasing PAn content of the composites.

Antisedimentation stabilities of the suspensions depend on the shape, size, density, and dielectric constant of the dispersed particles, type of base fluid and presence of surfactants which affect the zeta-potential, and consequently, the ER activity of the system. Among the PAn/K-feldspar composites studied, K1 having highest PAn content showed the highest antisedimentation stability with 24%, at the end of 20 days. Thus, the ER and creep-recovery measurements were carried out just on the composite coded K1.

sec.title: Effect of volume fraction and electric field strength on ER activity
sec.p:
Figure 5 shows the effect of volume fraction (φ) on electric field viscosity (ηE) for the K1/SO suspension system. The ηE of suspensions increased slightly up to φ = 5%, sharply up to φ = 20%, and then almost leveled off. This trend is due to the increased electric field-induced polarization forces acting between the dispersed particles with increasing φ. The magnitude of this polarization forces (Fp) in the direction of E is: (2) where ε2 is the dielectric constant of the particle, ρ the distance between particles, and r the radius of the particle.31 When E was applied to the suspensions, Fp caused the aggregation of particles and stronger fibrillar (or chain) structure formation occurred between the upper and lower plates of the rheometer. This fibrillar structure is across the direction of the shear field and leads to an enhanced ηE. Figure 5.
Effect of volume fraction on viscosity. Notes: Sample, K1/SO, T = 25°C, γ· = 1.0 s−1.

ER efficiency [(ηE ≠ 0 – ηE = 0)/ηE = 0] of PAn/K-feldspar composites was observed to increase with rising PAn content (Figure 6), as a result of dominant electric field induced viscous forces (Fv) which has the magnitude:32 (3) where ηs is the viscosity of the suspension and γ· the average shear rate. Similar behaviors are reported for PAn-derivatives/SO,25 PAn-montmorillonite nanocomposite,32 and PAn/TiO2/SO suspensions.33 Figure 6.
Effect of PAn content on ER efficiency. Notes: ϕ = 20%, E = 0, and E = 2.5 kV mm−1, T = 25°C, γ· = 1.0 s−1.

On the other hand, when the effect of particle volume fraction on ER efficiency was examined just for the K1/SO system, the ER efficiency increased with rising particle volume fraction up to φ = 20% and then leveled off;34 thus for the rest of the ER measurements this volume fraction was used.

Electric field induced shear stress (τE) of the K1/SO suspension system was observed to increase with rising E and φ; and reached to τE = 64 Pa at E = 2.5 kV mm−1 (Figure 7). Figure 7.
Effect of E on shear stress. Notes: Sample, K1/SO, T = 25°C, γ· = 1.0 s−1.

sec.title: Effect of shear rate on shear stress and electric field viscosity
sec.p:
Shear stress (τ) of the suspensions increased with increasing shear rate (γ·) (Figure 8). Besides, the viscosities of K1/SO system were observed to decrease especially at low γ· regions with typical curves of shear thinning non-Newtonian viscoelastic behavior both under E = 0 and E = 2.5 kV mm−1 conditions. The particles in a suspension are affected by the hydrodynamic interactions and the viscous forces. These behaviors of the particles are due to the microstructural changes in the suspension, which is due to the dominant character of the deformation rate of ER-fibrils to the reformation rate at the higher γ· values. The other suspension systems investigated in this study (K2/SO, K3/SO, K4/SO, K-feldspar/SO) also showed similar flow behaviors, as observed for K1/SO system. They showed a Bingham flow behavior both under E = 0 and E = 2.5 kV mm−1 conditions. The increase of τ was dominant in the low γ· region, on the other hand smaller enhancement was observed in the high γ· region in which hydrodynamic forces are dominant.35 Similar behaviors are reported in the literature for other PAn containing composites.36,37 Figure 8.
Effect of shear rate on shear stress and viscosity. Notes: Sample, K1/SO, φ = 20%, T = 25°C.

Yield stress (τy) values of all the composites/SO systems were calculated from the γ·-τ graphs obtained at CR mode by extrapolating the flow curve to γ· = 0 s−1 (φ = 20%, E = 2.5 kV mm−1). The moduli observed were in the linear response regime. The calculated τy values of the composites with PAn content are shown in Figure 9. The τy was observed to continuously increase with rising PAn content under E = 2.5 kV mm−1, which may be attributed to the effectiveness of polarization forces acting between the PAn particles in the suspension under E. The increments on yield stress [Δτy = τy(E = 2.5) − τy(E = 0)] were in the following order: Δτy(K1) = 63.8 Pa > Δτy(K2) = 39.4 Pa > Δτy(K3) = 28.4 Pa > Δτy(K4) = 25.1 Pa. The Δτy values clearly indicate that, although the Bingham plastic behavior is shown in all the PAn/K-feldspar composite/SO suspensions, different ER effects are shown, depending on the relative PAn content. Figure 9.
Change in yield stress of materials with PAn content. Notes: φ = 20%, T = 25°C. Figure 10.
Effect of E on yield stress. Notes: Sample, K1/SO, T = 25°C.

Several models have been proposed to describe the ER phenomena via shear stress equations. The original model is called ‘polarization model’ which attributes the ER phenomena to the attractive forces acting between the dispersed particles. This polarization model shows excellent agreement with the data for small φ and E values. (4) where β = (Kp − Kf)/(Kp + 2Kf) is the dimensionless dielectric mismatch parameter at dc or low frequency ac fields given by Conrad38 and Davis.39 Here, Kp and Kf are the dielectric permittivities of the particle and the fluid, respectively. However, it was observed in our experiments that, τy data significantly deviate from Equation (4) and better represented by the power law: τ ∝ En. The τy observed for K1/SO system was proportional to E1.3 at E > 1 kV mm−1 and φ = 20%; and typically approaches toE0.6 at E < 1 kV mm−1 conditions; thus E = 1.0 kV mm−1 is thought to be the critical electric field strength (Ec) for this system to be effectively ER active (Figure 10).

sec.title: Effect of temperature on shear stress
sec.p: The shear stress of ER fluid is influenced by the temperature of the environment because of polarizability of the disperse phase’s being temperature-dependent. Generally, the electrical conductivity of the ER fluid increases with increasing temperature. Temperature enhancement facilitates interfacial polarization as a result of the increased mismatch in σ between the two phases.40 On the other hand, temperature directly affects thermal motions of the dispersed particles, which lead to lower stability under E and decrease the ER performance. So, ER activity of the suspension systems become intensified or weakened depending on which factor is dominant at that temperature.

A temperature sweep was carried out between 15°C and 80°C for all the materials studied to examine the behavior of τ for PAn/K-feldspar composite/SO systems at various temperatures (Figure 11). The τ of the materials clearly increased with raising temperature. The improvement was attributed to the dielectric mismatch between the composite particles and the carrier fluid (SO) and a local polarization of the electric field induced particles. The enhancement of σ due to temperature-increment is caused by the increased polarization force on the chain structure, which undergoes to enhanced τ. The increments in shear stresses (Δτ) = τ80°C – τ15°C) were in the order of: ΔτK2 (55.7 Pa) > ΔτK1 (37.7 Pa)>ΔτK3 (26.1 Pa) > ΔτK4 (24.2 Pa) > ΔτK-Feldspar (5.5 Pa). From the closer processing of data, it was clearly seen that, the smaller Δτ value was determined for K-feldspar/SO system whereas; Δτ of the K1/SO system was almost seven-fold higher compared to K-feldspar/SO, which has the highest amount of PAn content. Figure 11.
Change of shear stress with temperature. Notes: φ = 20%, γ· = 1.0 s−1, E = 2.0 kV mm−1.

sec.title: Effect of frequency on elasticity modulus
sec.p:
The external frequency (f) is an important factor for characterizing the dynamic viscoelastic properties of ER fluids.41 Figure 12 shows the change in elasticity modulus (G′) with f, indicating that G′ is slightly increased with raising f. It can be predicted that an ER fluid shows a solid-like viscoelastic behavior in the linear viscoelastic region as a result of the formation of particle chain structures under E = 2.5 kV mm−1, which do not relax at a given range of f; and these PAn/K-feldspar composite materials may be used for vibration dumping purposes. Figure 12.
Change of elasticity modulus with frequency. Notes: φ = 20%, E = 2.5 kV mm−1, τ = 1 Pa, T = 25°C.

sec.title: Creep and creep-recovery tests
sec.p:
Figure 13 shows the creep and creep-recovery behavior of K1/SO system at various electric field strengths. During the creep experiment, a constant stress (τ = 10 Pa) was applied instantaneously (for t = 20 s) to the suspension, then the applied stress was removed and the time-dependent deformation was recorded. The strain (γ) was measured as a function of time under E = 0 (Figure 13(a)) and E ≠ 0 kV mm−1 (Figure 13(b)) conditions. The γ linearly increased with time and K1/SO system behaved as purely viscous material. This may be attributed to the persistently deformation under τ without E; and no recovery took place after removing the applied τ. On the other hand, the K1/SO system was in the non-linear viscoelastic regime at each E applied. In the creep phase, a decrease in the instantaneous γ was observed with the increase of E indicating that the elastic-γ response increases with the increase in E. After removal of the applied τ, the recovery portion increased with increasing E. The recovery (%) was calculated from the following equation:42 Figure 13.
Effect of E on creep response of K1/SO system under: (a) E = 0 kV mm−1 and (b) E ≠ 0 kV mm−1. Notes: φ = 20%, τ0 = 10 Pa, T = 25°C. (5) where γi is the total strain acquired before removing the applied stress and γf the average steady state strain after removing the applied stress. The recovery (%) was as following:

Also, the effect of applied τ on creep response of K1/SO system under a fixed E (E = 2.5 kV mm−1) was investigated and results obtained are depicted on Figure 14. The recovery (%) was observed to decrease with increasing applied τ, as expected. The recovery (%) of K1/SO system was as following: (81.6%)τ = 10 Pa > (48.0%) τ = 30 Pa > (8.4%)τ = 60 Pa < (6.5%)τ = 80 Pa. The creep-recovery experiments clearly indicate that the PAn/K-feldspar/SO is a smart ER active system and behaves like an elastic material at low stresses and has a potential of vibration damping capacity. Figure 14.
Effect of various applied stress on creep response of K1/SO system. Notes: φ = 20%, E = 2.5 kV mm−1, T = 25°C.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, synthesis, characterization, ER properties, and creep-recovery response of the PAn/K-feldspar conducting composites having various amounts of PAn is presented. Characterization results showed the successful formation of the composites. TGA results revealed that PAn/K-feldspar composites had higher thermal stability than PAn. It was observed that average particle sizes and densities of the materials were slightly decreased with increasing PAn content of the composites. Among the PAn/K-feldspar composites studied, K1 having highest PAn content showed the highest antisedimentation stability. ER activity of all the suspensions was observed to increase slightly with increasing φ, E, and T; and decrease with increasing γ·. The composites were observed to show a shear-thinning non-Newtonian viscoelastic behavior both under E = 0 and E = 2.5 kV mm−1 conditions. It was found that the yield stress increased with increasing PAn content under E ≠ 0 kV mm−1. The elasticity moduli of the composites were observed to show vibration damping capacity, thus they were classified as smart materials. Non-linear recoverable viscoelastic creep-recovery behavior was observed for PAn/K-feldspar systems under E and the %recovery increased with applied E and decreased with increasing applied shear stress.

ack.p: The authors thank The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TUBITAK) for providing the financial support of this study (project no. TBAG/107 T 711) and for the scholarship provided for O. Erol (BIDEB).
